content:
I think that's a wonderful idea! Having a physical binder or scrapbook can provide a tactile and nostalgic experience, especially when sharing the recipes and stories with family members or younger generations. It's a great way to create a sense of continuity and connection to the past.

Using a note-taking app like Evernote or OneNote is an excellent choice for digital organization, and creating separate notebooks and tags will make it easy to navigate and search the recipes. The recipe management tools you mentioned, Paprika Recipe Manager and BigOven, can also be very useful for meal planning and cooking.

By having both digital and physical archives, you'll be able to:

* Easily access and share recipes with family members or online communities
* Create a physical keepsake that can be passed down through generations
* Take advantage of the search and filtering capabilities of digital tools
* Enjoy the tactile experience of flipping through a physical book

When creating the physical binder or scrapbook, you might consider adding some personal touches, such as:

* Handwritten notes or stories from family members
* Photos of your grandmother, family gatherings, or special occasions where the recipes were served
* Recipe cards or clippings from old cookbooks or magazines
* Memorabilia like ticket stubs, postcards, or other keepsakes related to the recipes or family history
* Decorative paper, stickers, or other embellishments to make the binder visually appealing

Remember to choose a binder or scrapbook that is acid-free and archival-quality to ensure the longevity of the materials.

How do you plan to involve your family members in the creation of the physical binder or scrapbook? Will you have them contribute their own stories, photos, or recipes?
